introduction.p: A potato is placed in an oven, and the potato's temperature F (in degrees Fahrenheit) at various points in time is taken and recorded in the following table. Time t is measured in minutes.

statement.p: Use a central difference to estimate the instantaneous rate of change of the temperature of the potato at t= 30. Include units on your answer.

solution.p:
Using the central difference, we find that
F'(30) \approx \frac{F(45)-F(15)}{45-15} = \frac{296-180.5}{30} = 3.85
degrees per minute.

statement.p: Use a central difference to estimate the instantaneous rate of change of the temperature of the potato at t= 60. Include units on your answer.

solution.p:
Using the central difference, we find that
F'(60) \approx \frac{F(75)-F(45)}{75-45} = \frac{342.8-296}{30} = 1.56
degrees per minute.

statement.p: Without doing any calculation, which do you expect to be greater: F'(75) or F'(90)? Why?

hint.p: Is F changing faster at t = 75 or at t = 90?

solution.p: Over each subsequent time interval, we see that the amount of increase in the potato's temperature gets less and less, thus we expect the value of F'(t) to get smaller and smaller as time goes on. We therefore expect F'(75) \gt F'(90).

statement.p: Suppose it is given that F(64) = 330.28 and F'(64) = 1.341. What are the units on these two quantities? What do you expect the temperature of the potato to be when t = 65? when t = 66? Why?

hint.p: Remember that the units on F' will be degrees Fahrenheit per minute.

answer.p: The value F(64) = 330.28 is the temperature of the potato in degrees Fahrenheit at time 64, while F'(64) = 1.341 measures the instantaneous rate of change of the potato's temperature with respect to time at the instant t = 64, and its units are degrees per minute. Because at time t = 64 the potato's temperature is increasing at 1.341 degrees per minute, we expect that at t = 65, the temperature will be about 1.341 degrees greater than at t = 64, or in other words F(65) \approx 330.28 + 1.341 = 331.621. Similarly, at t = 66, two minutes have elapsed from t = 64, so we expect an increase of 2 \cdot 1.341 degrees: F(66) \approx 330.28 + 2 \cdot 1.341 = 332.962.

statement.p: Write a couple of careful sentences that describe the behavior of the temperature of the potato on the time interval [0,90], as well as the behavior of the instantaneous rate of change of the temperature of the potato on the same time interval.

hint.p: Be careful to distinguish between the temperature, F, and the rate of change of temperature, F', in your commentary.

answer.p: Throughout the time interval [0,90], the temperature F of the potato is increasing. But as time goes on, the rate at which the temperature is rising appears to be decreasing. That is, while the values of F continue to get larger as time progresses, the values of F' are getting smaller (while still remaining positive). We thus might say that the temperature of the potato is increasing, but at a decreasing rate.
